That address doesn't necessarily belong to the attacker. It's possible that he sent directly to an exchange, where they go into a general pool, and he gets out other crypto. They should freeze and investigate if any exchange is affected, which is what they are doing, presumably.

There is a simple send. It is on the blockchain. The coins at that address are rendered immovable by a patch at some, but probably not all, exchanges. But they may already have been trades for other crypto. They may yet be traded at an exchange that has not upgraded.
